raw_text:
World tour for top video gamers
 
 Two UK gamers are about to embark on a world tour as part of the most lucrative-ever global games tournament.
 
 Aaron Foster and David Treacy have won the right to take part in a tournament offering $1m in total prize money. The cash will be handed out over 10 separate competitions in a continent-hopping contest organised by the Cyberathlete Professional League. As part of their prize the pair will have their travel costs paid to ensure they can get to the different bouts.
 
 The CPL World Tour kicks off in mid-February and the first leg will be in Istanbul. All ten bouts of the tournament will be played throughout 2005, each one in a different country. At each stop $50,000 in prize money will be up for grabs. The tournament champion for each leg of the CPL World Tour will walk away with a $15,000 prize. The winner of the grand final will get a prize purse of $150,000 from a total pot of $500,000.
 
 Winners of each stage of the tour automatically get a place at the next stop. The world tour stops are open to any keen gamer that registers. Online registration for the first stop opens this weekend. Some pro-players are winning a spot at the tour destinations through qualifying events organised by CPL partners. Winners at these qualifiers get seeded higher in the elimination parts of each tournament. Mr Foster and Mr Treacy get the chance to attend the World Tour as members of the UK's Four-Kings gaming clan. Towards the end of 2004 Four-Kings staged a series of online Painkiller competitions to reveal the UK's top players of the PC game. The best eight players met face-to-face in a special elimination event in late December where Mr Foster and Mr Tracey proved their prowess at Painkiller. As part of their prize the pair also get a contract with Four-Kings Intel which is one of the UK's few pro-gaming teams. "There are a lot of people who take gaming very seriously and support their local or national team with the same passion as any other sport," said Simon Bysshe who filmed the event for Four-Kings and Intel. More than 80,000 people have downloaded the movie of the tournament highlights. "Professional gaming is here to stay and will only grow in popularity," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Aaron Foster and David Treacy are participating in a £1m world tour as part of the Cyberathlete Professional League's CPL World Tour. The tour consists of 10 separate competitions, each taking place in a different country, with $50,000 prize money up for grabs at each stop. Winners from each stage automatically get a spot at the next stop and can earn higher seeding and a contract with Four-Kings Intel through online registration.
llama3.2:3b: UK gamers Aaron Foster and David Treacy are embarking on a world tour as part of the Cyberathlete Professional League's $1m tournament, with travel costs covered. The 10-leg tournament kicks off in mid-February, with each leg offering $50,000 in prize money, culminating in a grand final worth $150,000. Winners of each stage automatically qualify for the next stop and have access to online registration.

The tour spans ten stages in 2005, each offering $50,000 in prize money for winners of each leg. The final winner takes home $150,000 from a $500,000 total prize pool. Winners advance to the next stage automatically and online registration opens this weekend.  Four-Kings, a UK gaming team, selected Foster and Treacy after successful online Painkiller competitions, granting them a contract with Four-Kings Intel.

Aaron Foster and David Treacy will participate in the Cyberathlete Professional League World Tour 2005, winning $1 million in total prize money distributed over ten regional events. Travel costs are fully covered to ensure they can attend each event. Each stage awards $50k plus a $15k grand prize winner, with the grand final winner receiving $150k from a $500k pot. They will join Four-Kings gaming and their team as members of the UK's Four-Kings clans. registration for the first stop is now available online this weekend. Top players qualify through competitions in December 2004, with winners seeded higher in elimination rounds. Mr. Foster and Treacy will join as members of Four-Kings, and they won a regional event last December.
tinyllama:1.1b: Nel mese di febbraio ebbe inizio un tour mondiale con una somma di $1m di premi da assegnare a vincitori di ogni leg, tenendo a fianco $50,000 di premi ad entrambi gli eventi. L'evento era organizzato dall'Alleanza Professionale Giochi Liberi (CPL) e non si sarebbero disputati le stagioni 2004 ed il 2005, a causa della pandemia mondiale di COVID-19. Questi due gamers statunitensi erano stati selezionati per la prima leg del World Tour come vincitori della competizione online Four-Kings. Tutti gli altri giocatori che hanno partecipato ai qualificatori e sono stati convocati alla World Tour sono stati dichiarati campioni di un determinato Painkiller evento. La squadra di Intel, la quale era la sola pro-gaming squadra nazionale e non ha alcun costruttore, ha pagato $150,000 in premi per il suo giocatore. Questo World Tour è stato organizzato dall'Alleanza Professionale Giochi Liberi (CPL) e non si sarebbero disputati le stagioni 2004 ed il 2005, a causa della pandemia mondiale di COVID-19.

The CPL World Tour will begin in mid-February with its first leg taking place in Istanbul, Turkey. Each stop on the tour will host $50,000 worth of prize money. In addition to enjoying the excitement of gaming competition, players will also benefit from winning the guaranteed $15,000 prize for each leg of the tournament. The winner of each stage automatically earns a spot at the next stop, and qualifying events will also be held for online gamers to secure spots in the elimination part of the tour.

Winners of each stage automatically get a place at the next stop, and online registration is open to any serious gamer who registers. Some gamers can qualify by winning a spot through qualifying events organised by CPL partners, which increases their seeded chances in each tournament.
